Description: Increase of immunosupression
Risk of possibly fatal generalized vaccine disease
Comment: as well as for the three months following the end of the treatment.

Description: Increased risk of undesirable effects (concentration dependent) of the rhabdomyolysis type.
Comment: If possible, stop the treatment with the HMG-COA Reductase Inhibitor before starting the treatment with fusidic acid or use another antibiotic.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the fusidic acid due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the therapy with ombitasvir+paritaprevir
Risk of increase of the effects of the botulinum toxin with the aminoglycosides (by extrapolation from the effects observed during the course of the botulism)
Comment: Use another antibiotic.

Description: Risk of excessive bradycardia (addition of the effects)
Increase of the bradycardia inducing effects which can have fatal consequences. The beta-blocking agents are even more at risk since they inhibit the adrenergic compensation mechanisms
Comment: Clinical monitoring and sustained EKG during the 24 hours following the first dose.

Drug 2 Class Name: SUBSTANCES THAT TEND TO INDUCE TORSADES DE POINTES
Description: Increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias, especially of torsades de pointes
Comment: Clinical monitoring and EKG during the administration of these together.

Description: Risk of increase of pulmonary toxicity
Increase of the concentrations of the active metabolite of the brentuximab, with risk of neutropenia
Risk of increase or decrease of the effects of the buprenorphine, due to simultaneous inhibition and acceleration of its metabolism by the protease inhibitor
With the buprenorphine used in opioid replacement therapy: increased risk of respiratory depression which could be fatal.
Comment: Evaluate carefully the risk/benefits relationship of administering these substances together. Inform the patient of the necessity of adhering to the prescribed dosages.

Description: Risk of increase or of decrease of the effects of the A to take into account buprenorphine [sic], simultaneously by inhibition and acceleration of its metabolism by the protease inhibitor.
Risk of increase or decrease of the effects of the buprenorphine, due to both inhibition and acceleration of its metabolism by the protease inhibitor
Increase of the concentrations of buprenorphine due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism, with risk of increase of its undesirable effects
Comment: Clinical monitoring and adjustment of the dosage of the buprenorphine during the treatment with the inhibitor and, if the situation requires, after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the concentrations of buprenorphine due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism, with risk of increase of its undesirable effects
Comment: Clinical monitoring and adjustment of the dosage of the buprenorphine during the treatment with the inhibitor and, if the situation requires, after it is stopped.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the cloripramine due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the bupropion
Comment: Clinical monitoring. If needed, adjustment of the dosage of the clomipramine during the treatment with the bupropion.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the desipramine due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the bupropion
Comment: Clinical monitoring. If needed, adjustment of the dosage of the desipramine during the treatment with the bupropion.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the flecainide due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the bupropion
Comment: Clinical monitoring. If needed, adjustment of the dosage of the flecainide during the treatment with the bupropion.

Description: Risk of hypertensive crises. From the fact of the length of action of the MAOI, this interaction is still theoretically possible two weeks after it is stopped

Drug 2 Class Name: REVERSIBLE MAOI-A, INCLUDING LINEZOLIDE AND METHYLENE BLUE
Description: Risk of hypertensive crises
Risk of hypertensive crises
Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the mequitazine, due to inhibition of its metabolism by the enzyme inhibitor
With the metoprolol used for heart failure: risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the metoprolol due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the bupropion
Comment: Clinical monitoring. If needed, adjustment of the dosage of the metoprolol during the treatment with the bupropion

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the nortriptyline due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the bupropion
Comment: Clinical monitoring. If needed, adjustment of the dosage of the nortriptyline during the treatment with the bupropion.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the propafenone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the bupropion
Comment: Clinical monitoring. If needed, adjustment of the dosage of the propafenone during the treatment with the bupropion.

Description: Risk of reduction of the effectiveness of the tamoxifen, due to inhibition of the formation of its active metabolite by the terbinafine [sic]

Increase of the plasma concentrations of the tramadol due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the bupropion. In addition, risk of convulsions due to addition of the effects of the two medications
Risk of decrease of the concentrations of the bupropion, with increase of its active metabolite and increased toxicity
Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the buspirone
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the buspirone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the diltiazem, with increase of its undesirable effects
Comment: Clinical monitoring and adjustment of the dosage of the buspirone if necessary.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the buspirone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism, with substantial increase of sedation
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the buspirone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism, with substantial increase of sedation
Rick of increase of the undesirable effects of the buspirone due to decrease of its metabolism by the grapefruit
Decrease of the plasma concentrations of the buspirone due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the rifampicin
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible adjustment of the dosage of the buspirone during the treatment with rifampicin and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the buspirone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the verapamil, with increase of its undesirable effects.
Comment: Clinical monitoring and adjustment of the dosage of the buspirone if necessary.

Description: Risk of increase of the toxicity of the busulfan due to decrease of its clearance by the deferasirox
With the busulfan in large doses: doubling of the concentrations of busulfan by the itraconazole
With the busulfan in large doses: doubling of the concentrations of busulfan by the metronidazole
Decrease of the concentrations of the cytotoxic by increase of its metabolism by the inducer, with risk of lower effectiveness
Risk of increase of the undesirable dose dependent effects of the cabazitaxel due to inhibition of its metabolism by the enzymatic inducer
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible adjustment of the dosage of the cabazitaxel during the treatment with the enzymatic inhibitor.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of caffeine, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism
With the dipyridamole by injection: reduction of the vasodilator effect of the dipyridamole by the caffeine
Comment: Interrupt a caffeine based treatment at least 5 days before myocardial perfusion imaging with the dipyridamole and avoid consuming coffee, tea, chocolate, or cola during the 24 hours that precede the test.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of caffeine, which can lead to agitation and hallucinations, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism
In case of sudden discontinuation of consumption of coffee or of medications containing caffeine, risk of increase of the lithemia
Increase of the plasma concentrations of caffeine, due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism by the mexiletine
Increase of the plasma concentrations of caffeine, due to decrease of the hepatic metabolism of the caffeine
Possible increase of the plasma concentrations of the caffeine, with risk of overdose, due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible adjustment of the dosage of caffeine.

Description: Risk of reduction of the effectiveness of the lithium due to increase of its renal elimination by the calcitonin
Comment: Regular clinical and biological monitoring, especially at the beginning of the administration of the two substances together.

Description: Risk of rash, redness, and heat linked to an increase of the vasodilator effect
For the calcium salts administered via oral route: decrease of the digestive absorption of the bisphosphonates
Comment: Take calcium salts and antacids at a different time from the bisphosphonates (from 30 minutes minimum to more than 2 hours apart, if possible, depending on the bisphosphonate).

Description: Decrease of the digestive absorption of the tetracycline antibiotics
Comment: Take the calcium salts at a different time from the tetracycline antibiotics (more than two hours apart if possible).

Description: Risk of serious arrhythmias, even lethal ones, with the calcium salts administered by IV route.
Comment: -with the calcium salts via IV, except for parenteral supplementation

Description: Risk of hypercalcemia due to decrease of the urinary elimination of the calcium.
Decrease of the digestive absorption of the estramustine
Comment: Take the calcium salts at a different time from the estramustine (more than 2 hours apart, if possible).

Description: With the iron salts by oral route: decrease of the digestive absorption of the iron salts
Comment: Take the iron salts at a different time from meals and in the absence of calcium.

Description: Decrease of the absorption of the thyroid hormones
Comment: Take the calcium salts at a different time from the thyroid hormones (more than 2 hours apart, if possible).

Description: With the calcium salts administered by oral route: decrease of the digestive absorption of the strontium
Comment: Take the strontium at a different time from the calcium salts (more than two hours apart, if possible).

Description: Decrease of the digestive absorption of the zinc by the calcium
Comment: Take the calcium salts at a different time from the zinc (more than 2 hours apart, if possible).

Description: Risk of increase of serious infections
Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine with signs of overdose.
Comment: Clinical monitoring, and, if needed, testing of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine and possible reduction of its dosage

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: at the beginning of treatment, increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism by the cimetidine
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine, especially during the first days of treatment with the cimetidine

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine with signs of overdose, due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the active metabolite of the carbamazepine. In addition, decrease of the plasma concentrations of the clonazepam due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the carbamazepine
Comment: Clinincal monitoring, plasma dosages, and possible adjustment of the dosages of the two anticonvulsants

Description: Risk of increase of the serious hematological effects
Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine, with signs of overdose
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine and decrease of the digoxinemia
Comment: Exercise caution in the interpretation of the plasma concentrations.

Description: Risk of symptomatic hyponatremia
Comment: Clinical and biological monitoring. If possible, use another class of diuretics.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine with signs of overdose, due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism
Decrease of the plasma concentrations of ethosuximide
Comment: Clinical monitoring, plasma dosage of the ethosuximide and possible increase of its dosage.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the active metabolite of the carbamazepine. In addition, decrease of the plasma concentrations of felbamate due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the carbamazepine
Comment: Clinical monitoring, plasma dosages, and possible adjustment of the dosages of the two anticonvulsants.

Description: For doses of fluconazole >=200 mg per day: possible increase of the undesirable effects of the carbamazepine
Comment: Adjust the dosage of carbamazepine, during the antifungal treatmentand after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine with signs of overdose
Comment: Clinical monitoring, testing of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine, and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine during the treatment with the serotoninergic antidepressant and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine with signs of overdose
Comment: Clinical monitoring, testing of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine, and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine during the treatment with the serotoninergic antidepressant and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine with signs of overdose due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism
Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine with signs of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Clinical monitoring and. if needed, plasma dosage and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine.

Description: Risk of increase of the neurological effects (vertigo, ataxia, diplopia) of the carbamazepine when the lamotrigine is introduced
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine.

Description: Risk of neurotoxicity manifesting as disorders of the cerebellum, confusion, drowsiness, ataxia. These disorders are reversible when the treatment with lithium is stopped.
Risk of decrease of the plasma concentrations and of the effectiveness of the carbamazepine
Decrease of the plasma concentrations of nintedanib due to decrease of its absorption by the carbamazepine
Comment: Clinical monitoring during the administration of these substances together.

Description: Risk of decrease of the plasma concentrations of the olanzapine and of its therapeutic effectiveness, due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the carbamazepine
Comment: Clinical monitoring, and if needed, adjustment of the dosage of the olanzapine.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine, with risk of overdose, due to inhibition of its metabolism by the grapefruit
Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine with signs of overdose
Comment: Clinical monitoring, testing of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine during the treatment with the serotoninergic antidepressant and after it is stopped.

Description: Progressive decrease of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine and of its active metabolite without apparent modification of its anticonvulsive effectiveness
Comment: Use prudence with respect to the interpretation of the plasma concentrations.

Description: Reciprocal reduction of the plasma concentrations (increase of the metabolism without apparent modification of the anticonvulsive effectiveness)
Comment: Use prudence in the interpretation of the plasma concentrations.

Description: Decrease of the plasma concentrations and of the effectiveness of the carbamazepine due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the rifampicin
Comment: Clinical monitoring, testing of the plasma concentrations, and adjustment of the dosage of the carbamazepine during the treatment with the refampicin and after it is stopped.

Description: Risk of decrease of the active fraction of the risperidone and of its therapeutic effectiveness due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the carbamazepine
Comment: Clinical monitoring, and, if needed, adjustment of the dosage of the risperidone.

Description: Large decrease of the plasma concentrations of simvastatin, due to increase of its hepatic metabolism
Decrease of the concentrations of the topiramate with risk of lower effectiveness, due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the carbamazepine
Comment: Clinical monitoring, and if needed, adjustment of the dosage of the topiramate during the treatment with the carbamazepine and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the active metabolite of the carbamazepine with signs of overdose. In addition, decrease of the plasma concentrations of valproic acid due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the carbamazepine
Comment: Clinical monitoring, plasma dosages, and adjustment of the dosage of the two anticonvulsants.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increased bone marrow toxicity (inhibition of the metabolism of the carmustine)

With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the concentrations of the carvedilol, which can be dangerous in the case of treatment for heart failure due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the cimetidine
Comment: Use another gastric H2 receptor antagonist.

Description: Large decrease of the plasma concentrations of the carvedilol, due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the rifampicin
Comment: Regular clinical monitoring and adjustment of the dosage of the carvedilol during the treatment with the rifampicin. When the rifampicin is stopped, risk of large increase of the plasma concentrations of carvedilol imposing a reduction of the dosage and strict clinical monitoring.

Description: With the resin administered by oral and rectal routes: risk of colonic necrosis, possibly fatal
With the resin administered by oral and rectal routes: risk of colonic necrosis, possibly fatal
Increase of the nephrotoxicity of the aminoglycosides by the cefalotin is under discussion
Comment: Monitoring of renal function.

Description: Increase of the effect of the vitamin K antagonist and of the risk of hemorrhage
Comment: More frequent testing of the INR. Possible adjustment of the dosage of the vitamin K antagonist during the treatment with the cephalosporin and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the effect of the vitamin K antagonist and of the risk of hemorrhage
Comment: More frequent testing of the INR. Possible adjustment of the dosage of the vitamin K antagonist during the treatment with the cephalosporin and after it is stopped.

Description: Risk of variation of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin
Increase of the effect of the vitamin K antagonist and of the risk of hemorrhage
Comment: More frequent testing of the INR. Possible adjustment of the dosage of the vitamin K antagonist during the treatment with the cephalosporin and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the effect of the vitamin K antagonist and of the risk of hemorrhage
Comment: More frequent testing of the INR. Possible adjustment of the dosage of the vitamin K antagonist during the treatment with the cephalosporin and after it is stopped.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: accrued risk of drowsiness
Comment: Warn patients of the increase of risk when driving an automobile or using machinery.

Description: Risk of increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin and of the creatinemia
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of ciclosporin, testing of the renal function, and adjustment of the dosage during the administration of the substances together and after the chloroquine is stopped.

Description: Slowing of the elimination of the chloroquine and risk of overdose
Risk of clinical hypothyroidism in patients taking thyroid hormones in substitution therapy
Comment: Monitoring of serum concentrations of T3 and T4 and adjustment, if needed, of the dosage of the thyroid hormone during the treatment with the antimalarial and after it is stopped.

Description: With strong doses (100 mg per day of chlorpromazine): elevation of glycemia (decrease of the freeing of insulin)
Comment: Inform the patient and reinforce self monitoring of blood glucose. Possible adjustment of the dosage of the insulin durin the treatment with the neuroleptic and after it is stopped.

Description: With strong doses (100 mg per day of chlorpromazine): elevation of glycemia (decrease of the freeing of insulin)
Comment: Inform the patient and reinforce self monitoring of blood glucose. Possible adjustment of the dosage of the insulin durin the treatment with the neuroleptic and after it is stopped.

Description: Risk of variation of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin
Increase of the plasma concentrations of afatinib due to increase of its absorption by the ciclosporin
Comment: It is recommended that the ciclosporin be administered as far from the afatinib as possible, preferably an interval of 6 to 12 hours away from the administration of the dose of afatinib.

Description: Increase by nearly 5 times the plasma concentrations of aliskiren and increase of the risk of its undesirable effects.
Doubling of the concentrations of ambrisentan, with increase of the vasodilator effect (severe headaches )
Larger increase of the creatinemia than with ciclosporin alone, with increase of the nephrotoxic risk
Increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism, with risk of nephrotoxic effects
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of ciclosporin, testing of the renal function, and adjustment of the dosage of the ciclosporin during the treatment with the amiodarone

Description: With the amphotericin B administered by IV route: greater increase of the creatinemia than with ciclosporin alone (synergy of the nephrotoxic effects of the two substances)
With the ciclosporin administered orally:reduction of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin (decrease of its intestinal absorption).
Comment: Increase of the doses of ciclosporin according to testing of the plasma concentrations and reduction of the dosage after the treatment with the somatostatin analog is stopped

Description: Risk of addition of the nephrotoxic effects, especially with older patients.
Comment: Monitor renal function at the beginning of the treatment with the NSAI.

Description: Increased risk of undesirable effects (concentration-dependant) of the rhabodmyolysis type (decrease of the intestinal absorption of the cholesterol lowering medication)
Comment: Do not exceed the dosage of 10mg/day of atorvastatin. If the therapeutic objective is not reached at that dosage, use another statin not affected by this type of interaction.

Description: Risk of increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin and of the creatinemia
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of the ciclosporin, testing of renal function, and adjustment of the dosage during the administration of the two substances together and after the macrolide is stopped

Description: Large decrease of the blood concentrations of the ciclosporin and increase of the plasma concentrations of bosentan
Risk of increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin and of the creatinemia
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of the ciclosporin, testing of renal function, and adjustment of the dosage during the administration of the substances together and after the chloroquine is stopped.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin
Decrease of the blood concentrations of the immunosuppressant with risk of loss of immunosuppressive activity
Comment: Reinforce testing of the blood dosages of ciclosporin and possible increase of its dosage.

Description: Risk of addition of the undesirable neuromuscular effects and increase of the toxicity of the colchicine with risk of overdose due to inhibition of its elimination by the ciclosporin, especially in cases of pre-existing renal insufficiency
Increase by more than double of the plasma concentrations of dabigatran, with increase of the risk of bleeding
Increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of ciclosporin, testing of renal function, and adjustment of the dosage during the administration of the substances together and after it is stopped.

Drug 2 Class Name: POTASSIUM SPARING DIURETICS (ALONE OR IN COMBINATION)
Description: Potentially lethal hyperkalemia, especially when there is renal insufficiency (addition of the hyperkalemia inducing effects)

Risk of increase of the creatinemia without modification of the blood concentrations of the ciclosporin, even in the absence of fluid depletion. Also risk of hyperuricemia and of complications such as gout
Increase of the plasma concentrations of eribuline by the ciclosporin
Increase of the blood concentrations of the everolimus by the ciclosporin. The nephrotoxicity of the ciclosprorin is also increased when the two medications are administered together
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of the everolimus, possibly adjustment of the dosage, and testing of the renal function during the administration of the two together and after it is stopped.

Description: For one thing, increased risk of undesirable effects (concentration-dependent) of the rhabdomyolysis type, due to increase of the concentrations of ezetimibe; for another thing, possible increase of the concentrations of ciclosporin
Risk of increase of the nephrotoxicity of the ciclosporin
Comment: Clinical and biological monitoring of renal function during and after the administration of the two medications together.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the fidaxomicin.
Risk of increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin and of the creatinemia
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of the ciclosporin, testing of renal function, and adjustment of the dosage during the administration of these medications together and after the macrolide is stopped.

Description: Moderate increase of the blood concentrations of the immunosuppressant and larger increase of the concentrations of the lercanidipine
Comment: Separate the time when the two medications are taken. Blood concentration dosage of the immunosuppressant, and adjustment if necessary of its dosage during the administration of the medications together and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the toxicity of the methotrexate and of the ciclosporin with increase of the creatinemia: reciprocal decrease of the clearances of the two medications
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of ciclosporin and of methotrexate. Adjustment of the dosage if necessary during the administration of the two together and after it is stopped.

Description: With the methylprednisolone administered by IV route: possible increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin and of the creatinemia. Mecanism proposed: decrease of the hepatic elimination of the ciclosporin
Risk of increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin and of the creatinemia
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of the ciclosporin, testing of renal function, and adjustment of the dosage during the administration of the substances together and after the macrolide is stopped.

Description: Risk of decrease of the blood concentrations and of the effectiveness of the immunosuppressant
Risk of addition of undesirable effects of the gum disorders type.
Comment: Use another dihydropyridine.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the nintedanib due to increase of its absorption by the ciclosporin
Comment: Clinical monitoring during the administration of there substances together.

Description: Decrease of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin due to decrease of its intestinal absorption, with risk of loss of the immunosuppressive activity
Comment: Take the orlistat at a different time form the ciclosporin (at least 3 hours apart). Reinforce testing of blood dosages of the ciclosporin, especially at the beginning of the administration of the medications together, and at the time of a possible increase in the dosage of the orlistat.

Description: Increased risk of undesirable effects (concentration-dependant) of the rhabdomyolysis type, or of nephrotoxicity, due to decrease of the metabolism of the pitavastatin
Potentially lethal hyperkalemia, especially when there is renal insufficiency (addition of the hyperkalemia inducing effects)
Comment: Avoid the administration of these two substances together unless there is pre-existing hypokalemia.

Description: Increase of the effects of the prednisolone: characteristic Cushings appearance, reduction of tolerance of carbohydrates (decrease of clearance of the prednisolone)
Increase of more than double of the concentrations of the repaglinide due to increase of its absorption
Increased risk of undesirable effects (concentration-dependant) of the rhabdomyolysis type, or of nephrotoxicity, due to decrease of the metabolism of the rosuvastatin
Risk of increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin and of the creatinemia
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of the ciclosporin, testing of renal function, and adjustment of the dosage during the administration with the macrolide and after it is stopped.

Description: Increased risk of undesirable effects (concentration-dependant) of the rhabdomyolosis type due to decrease of the metabolism of the simvastatin
Comment: Do not exceed the dosage of 10mg/day of simavastatin. If the therapeutic objective is not reached at this dosage, use another statin not affected by this type of interaction.

Description: Increase of the blood concentrations of sirolimus by the ciclosporin. The nephrotoxicity of the ciclosporin is also increased when the two medications are administered together
Comment: It is recommended that the sirolimus be administered 4 hours after the cyclosporine. Testing of the renal function, during the administration of the two medications together and after it is stopped.

Description: Decrease of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin due to increase of its metabolism by the sulfinpyrazone
Comment: Testing of blood concentrations of ciclosporin and possible adjustment of its dosage during the treatment with sulfinpyrazone and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of tenofovir alafenamide due to increase of its absorption
Comment: In case of administration with the ciclosporin, the dose of tenofovir alafenamide must be limited to 10 mg per day.

Description: Decrease of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin
Comment: Testing of blood concentrations of ciclosporin and possible adjustment of its dosage during the treatment with terbinafine and after it is stopped.

Description: Decrease of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin
Comment: Increase of the dosage of the ciclosporin according to testing of the blood concentrations. Reduction of the dosage when the ticlodipine is stopped.

Description: With the trimethoprim (alone or in combination) by oral route: increase of the creatinemia with possible decrease of the blood concentrations of ciclosporinWith the trimethoprim (alone or in combination) by IV route: the decrease of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin can be very large, with possible loss of immunosuppressant capacity
Increase of the blood concentrations of the ciclosporin (decrease of its hepatic metabolism), and increase of the risk of gum disorders
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of the ciclosporin, testing of the renal function, and adjustment of the dosage during the administration of the medications together and after it is stopped.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800mg/day: increase of the opioid analgesic's effect of respiratory depression due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Adjust the dosage of the alfentanil when administered with the cimetidine.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the effect of the vitamin K antagonist and of the risk of hemorrhage (decrease of its hepatic metabolism)
Comment: More frequent testing of the INR. Possible adjustment of the dosage of the vitamin K antagonist during the treatment with the cimetidine and a week after it is stopped.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: at the beginning of treatment, increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism by the cimetidine
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine, especially during the first days of treatment with the cimetidine

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increased bone marrow toxicity (inhibition of the metabolism of the carmustine)

With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the concentrations of the carvedilol, which can be dangerous in the case of treatment for heart failure due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the cimetidine
Comment: Use another H2 receptor antagonist.

Description: With the cemitidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: accrued risk of drowsiness
Comment: Warn patients of the increase of risk when driving an automobile or using machinery.

Description: Slowing of the elimination of the chloroquine and risk of overdose
With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the blood concentrations of ciclosporin
With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: accrued risk of drowsiness
Comment: Warn the patient of the increase of risk when driving an automobile or using machinery.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the plasma concentrations of lidocaine with risk of undesirable neurological and cardiac effects (inhibition of the hepatic metabolism of the lidocaine)
Comment: Clinical monitoring, EKG, and possibly monitoring of the plasma concentrations of the lidocaine; if there is reason for it, adjustment of the dosage of the lidocaine during the treatment with the cimetidine and after it is stopped.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increased bone marrow toxicity (inhibition of the metabolism of the lomustine)
Increase of the plasma concentrations of methadone with overdose and increased risk of lengthening of the QT interval and of ventricular arrhythmias, notably of torsades de pointes.
Comment: Strengthen clinical and electrocardiographic monitoring; if needed, adjustment of the dosage of the methadone during the treatment with the cimetidine and after it is stopped.

Description: With the metoprolol used for heart failure, and the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the concentrations of the metoprolol, which can be dangerous in the case of treatment for heart failure, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the cimetadine
Comment: Clinical monitoring. If needed, adjustment of the dosage of the metoprolol during the treatment with the cimetidine

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the concentrations of the moclobemide, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Clinical monitoring with possible adjustment of the dosage of the moclobemide

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the hypotensive effect of the nifedipine due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism by the cimetidine
Comment: Increased clinical monitoring: adjust the dosage of the nifedipine during the treatment with the cimetidine and after it is stopped.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the plasma concentrations of phenytoin with the possibility of appearance of the usual signs of overdose
Comment: If administering the substances together cannot be avoided, strict clinical monitoring, plasma concentration dosages of the phenytoin, and possible adjustment of its dosage during the treatment with cimetidine and after it is stopped.

Description: With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: increase of the theophyllinemia with risk of overdose (decrease of the metabolism of the theophylline)
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possibly monitoring of the theophyllinemia. If there is reason for it, adjustment of the theophylline during the treatment with the cimetidine and after it is stopped.

Description: Very large increase of the plasma concentrations of dextromethorphan with risk of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the cinacalcet
Increase of the plasma concentrations of flecanaide with risk of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the cinacalcet
Comment: Clinical monitoring and reduction of the dosage of the flecainide during the treatment with cinacalcet.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the mequitazine, due to inhibition of its metabolism by the enzyme inhibitor
Increase of the plasma concentrations of metoprolol with risk of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the cinacalcet
Comment: Clinical monitoring and reduction of the dosage of the metoprolol during the treatment with cinacalcet.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of propafenone with risk of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the cinacalcet
Comment: Clinical monitoring and reduction of the dosage of the propafenone during the treatment with cinacalcet.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the vortioxetine due to large decrease of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible adjustment of the dosage of the vortioxetine during the treatment with the cinacalcet and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the concentrations of agomelatine, with risk of increase of its undesirable effects.
Increase of the plasma concentrations of caffeine, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism
Increase of the concentrations of clozapine with risk of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the ciprofloxacin
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible reduction of the dosage of the clozapine during the treatment with the ciprofloxacin and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the toxicity of the methotrexate due to inhibition of its renal tubular secretion by the ciprofloxacin
Variation, possibly large, of the concentrations of phenytoin in the case of treatment with ciprofloxacin
Comment: Clinical monitoring and testing of the plasma concentrations of the anticonvulsant during the treatment with ciprofloxacin and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the concentrations of ropinirole with risk of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the ciprofloxacin
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible reduction of the dosage of the ropinirole during the treatment with the ciprofloxacin and after it is stopped.

Drug 2 Class Name: SUBSTANCES THAT TEND TO INDUCE TORSADES DE POINTES
Description: Increased risk of ventricular arrythmias, especially of torsades de pointes.
Comment: Clinical monitoring and EKG during the administration of these substances together.

Description: Increase of the theophyllinemia with risk of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the ciprofloxacin
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possibly monitoring of the theophyllinemia

Description: Risk of facilitation of systemic uptake of the aluminum, especially in case of altered renal function.
Comment: Take the aluminum based gastrointestinal medications at a different time (more than 2 hours apart if possible) from the citrates, including natural citrates (citrus fruit juices).

Description: With women of child bearing age, risk of transformation of the acitretin into etretinate, a powerful agent of birth defects and malformations with a very prolonged half life (120 days), exposing the woman to a major risk of these birth defects and malformations of the child in case of pregnancy, during the treatment and two months after it ends.
Risk of increase of the hepatotoxicity of the methotrexate
Comment: If administering these substances together is judged necessary, strengthen liver function testing.

Description: Risk of decrease of the effectiveness of the cladribine by the lamivudine
Increase of the plasma concentrations of clarithyromycin and inhibition of the formation of its active metabolite
Comment: Regular clinical and biological monitoring, especially at the beginning of the administration of these together.

Description: Increased risk of undesirable effects (concentration-dependant) of the rhabodmyolysis type, due to decrease of the hepatic metabolism of the cholesterol lowering agent
Comment: Administer weaker doses of the cholesterol lowering agent. If the therapeutic objective is not reached, use another statin not affected by this type of interaction.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine with signs of overdose, due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible reduction of the dosage of the carbamazepine.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the dexamethasone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the enzymatic inhibitor, with risk of appearance of Cushings syndrome
Increase of the digoxinemia due to increase of its absorption
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possibly monitoring of the digoxinemia during the treatment with clarithromycin and after it is stopped.

Description: Increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias in predisposed subjects (congenital long QT syndrome)
Increase of the plasma concentrations of eribuline by the clarithromycin.
In the treatment of infections with Mycobacterium avium complex, risk of decrease of the effectiveness of the clarithromycin due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the etravirine
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the fidaxomicin
Risk of hypoglycemia due to increase of the absorption and of the plasma concentrations of the antidiabetic
Comment: Inform the patient, reinforce self-monitoring of blood glucose, and possibly adjust the dosage of the blood glucose lowering sulfonamide during the treatment with the clarithromycin.

Description: Risk of hypoglycemia due to increase of the absorption and of the plasma concentrations of the antidiabetic.
Comment: Inform the patient, reinforce self-monitoring of blood glucose, and possibly adjust the dosage of the blood glucose lowering sulfonamide during the treatment with the clarithromycin

Description: Increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias, especially of torsades de pointes
Comment: If it is possible, interrupt the macrolide. If administering these two together cannot be avoided, test of the QT before hand and monitor EKG.

Description: Very large increase of the blood concentrations of the immunosuppressant due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: If these are administered together, strict testing of the renal function, blood concentration dosage of the immunosuppressant, and possible adjustment of the dosage.

Description: Increase of the concentrations of the clarithromycin and of its active metabolite due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the protease inhibitor
Comment: Regular clinical and biological monitoring, especially at the beginning of treatment.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the linezolide by the clarithromycin due to increase of its absorption
Increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias, especially of torsades de pointes
Comment: If this is possible, interrupt the medication tending to induce torsades de pointes. If administering these medications together cannot be avoided, testing of the QT before hand and EKG monitoring.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of midazolam due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism with increase of sedation.
Comment: -with the midazolam by mouth

Description: Risk of ventricular arrhythmias, especially of torsades de pointes
Increase of the plasma concentration of the pravastatin by the clarithromycin
Comment: Clinical and biological monitoring during the treatment with the antibiotic

Description: Risk of hypoglycemia due to increase of the plasma concentrations of the repaglinide
Comment: Inform the patient, reinforce self-monitoring of blood glucose and possibly adjust the dosage of the hypoglycemic agent during the treatment with the clarithromycin.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the rifabutin (uveitis) due to increase of its concentrations and those of its active metabolite by the clarithromycin. In addition, increase of the metabolism of the clarithromycin by the rifabutin, with increase of the concentrations of its active metabolite
Comment: Regular clinical and biological monitoring, especially at the beginning of the administration of the two medications together.

Description: Decrease of the plasma concentrations and risk of lower effectiveness of the clarithromycin, especially with the HIV patient, due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the rifampacin
Comment: Regular clinical and biological monitoring.

Description: Increased risk of undesirable effects (contentration-dependent) of the rhabdomyolysis type, due to decrease of the hepatic metabolism of the cholesterol lowering agent

Drug 2 Class Name: SUBSTANCES THAT TEND TO INDUCE TORSADES DE POINTES
Description: Increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias, especially of torsades de points
Comment: Clinical monitoring and EKG during the administration of these medications together.

Comment: Inform the patient, reinforce self-monitoring of blood glucose and possibly adjust the dosage of the blood glucose lowering sulfonamide during the treatment with the clarithromycin.

Description: Risk of increase of the theophyllinemia, particularly with children
Increase of the concentrations of venlafaxine with risk of overdose
Risk of increase of the toxicity of the antimitotic due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the clarithromycin.

Description: Increase of the effect of the Vitamin K antagonist and of the risk of hemorrhage.

Description: Decrease of the blood concentrations of the immunosuppressant with risk of loss of immunosuppressive activity

Comment: Reinforced testing of the blood dosages of tacrolimus and possible increase of its dosage.

Comment: Clinical monitoring, plasma dosage, when that is possible, of the anticonvulsant taken with the stiripentol and possible adjustment of the dosage of the anticonvulsant taken with it as well.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the clomipramine due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the bupropion
Comment: Clinical monitoring. If needed, adjustment of the dosage of the clomipramine during the treatment with the bupropion.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the active metabolite of the carbamazepine. In addition, decrease of the plasma concentrations of the clonazepam due to increase of its hepatic metabolism by the carbamazepine
Comment: Clinical monitoring, plasma dosages, and possible adjustment of the dosages of the two anticonvulsants

Description: Described for desipramine, imipramine:inhibition of the antihypertensive effect of the clonidine (antagonism at the level of the adrenergic receptors)
Disorders of autoregulation (disorders of atrioventricular conduction due to addition of the negative effects on conduction)

Increase of the risk of hemorrhage due to addition of the platelet antiagregation action

Increase of the plasma concentrations of phenytoin with signs of overdose (inhibition of the metabolism of the phenytoin)

Description: Increase of the concentrations of the repaglinide by the clopidogrel, with risk of increase of the undesirable effects.

Risk of increase of the serious hematological effects
Increase of the concentrations of clozapine with risk of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the ciprofloxacin
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible reduction of the dosage of the clozapine during the treatment with the ciprofloxacin and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of clozapine with signs of overdose
Comment: Increased clinical monitoring; if needed, adjustment of the dosage of the clozapine during the treatment with the fluvoxamine and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the neurotoxicity of the antimitotic due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the cobicistat
Comment: Strict clinical monitoring and possible adjustment of the dosage of the antimitotic

Comment: Limit the amount of adrenaline, for example: less than 0.1 mg of adrenaline in 10 minutes or 0.3 mg in an hour for an adult.

Risk of deficiency of cyanocobalamin after prolonged treatment (several years), the reduction of gastric acidity by these medications can diminish the digestive absorption of the vitamin B12.

Comment: Take the calcium salts at a different time from the tetracycline antibiotic (more than two hours apart, if possible).

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of afatinib by increase of its absorption by the ciclosporin

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of afatinib by increase of its absorption by the ketoconazole.

Description: Decrease of the plasma concentrations of the afatinib due to increase of its metabolism by the rifampicin

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of afatinib by increase of its absorption by the verapamil.

Risk of significant hypotension (synergic effect) capable of aggravating the state of myocardial ischemia and especially provoking an acute coronary accident
Increase of the risk of hypotension, especially orthostatic.
Risk of significant hypotension (synergic effect).
Large decrease of the plasma concentrations of the albendazole and of its active metabolite by the inducer, with risk of lower effectiveness.
Comment: Clinical monitoring of the therapeutic response and possible adjustment of the dosage of the albendazole during the treatment with the enzymatic inducer and after it is stopped.

Description: Large decrease of the plasma concentrations of the albendazole and of its active metabolite by the ritonavir, with risk of lower effectiveness.
Comment: Clinical monitoring of the therapeutic response and possible adjustment of the dosage of the albendazole during the treatment with the enzymatic inducer [sic] and after it is stopped.

Description: Large decrease of the plasma concentrations of the albendazole and of its active metabolite by the inducer, with risk of lower effectiveness.
Comment: Clinical monitoring of the therapeutic response and possible adjustment of the dosage of the albendazole during the treatment with the enzymatic inducer and after it is stopped.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the desipramine due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the bupropion
Comment: Clinical monitoring. If needed, adjustment of the dosage of the desipramine during the treatment with the bupropion.

Description: Decrease of the effectiveness of the dexamethasone, due to increase of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Adjustment of the dosage of the dexamethasone.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the dexamethasone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the enzymatic inhibitor, with risk of appearance of Cushing's syndrome
With the dexamethasone for systemic use, risk of significant decrease of the plasma concentrations of daclatasvir due to increase of it hepatic metabolism by the inducer
Comment: With the exception of dexamethasone administered in a single dose.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the dexamethasone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the enzymatic inhibitor, with risk of appearance of Cushing's syndrome
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the dexamethasone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the protease inhibitor, with risk of appearance of Cushing's syndrome
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the dexamethasone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the enzymatic inhibitor, with risk of appearance of Cushing's syndrome
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the dexamethasone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the enzymatic inhibitor, with risk of appearance of Cushing's syndrome
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the dexamethasone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the enzymatic inhibitor, with risk of appearance of Cushing's syndrome
Decrease of the plasma concentrations of the praziquantel, with risk of failure of the treatment, due to increase of the hepatic metabolism of the praziquantel by the dexamethasone.
Comment: Separate the administration of the two medications by at least a week.

Description: With the dexmethasone for systemic use, risk of decrease of the plasma concentrations of rilpivirine due to increase of its hepatic metaolism by the dexamethasone
Comment: With the exception of dexamethasone administered in a single dose.

Description: With the dexmethasone for systemic use, risk of decrease of the plasma concentrations of simeprevir by increase of its hepatic metaolism by the dexamethasone
Comment: With the exception of dexamethasone administered in a single dose.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the dexamethasone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the enzymatic inhibitor, with risk of appearance of Cushing's syndrome
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the dexamethasone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the enzymatic inhibitor, with risk of appearance of Cushing's syndrome

Description: Increase of the risk of hemorrhage (inhibition of the platelet function by the dextran 40)

Drug 2 Class Name: UNFRACTIONATED HEPARIN (CURATIVE DOSES AND/OR OLDER PATIENT)
Description: Increase of the risk of hemorrhage (inhibition of the platelet function by the dextran 40)
Very large increase of the plasma concentrations of dextromethorphan with risk of overdose, due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the cinacalcet
Risk of appearance of a serotonin syndrome: diarrhea, tachycardia, sweats, trembling, confusion, even coma

Drug 2 Class Name: REVERSIBLE MAOI-A, INCLUDING LINEZOLIDE AND METHYLENE BLUE
Description: Risk of appearance of a serotonin syndrome: diarrhea, tachycardia, sweats, trembling, confusion, even coma
Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the buspirone
With the cimetidine used in doses greater than or equal to 800 mg/day: accrued risk of drowsiness
Comment: Warn the patients of the increase of risk when driving an automobile or using machinery.

Description: Unpredictable variations: the plasma concentrations of phenytoin can increase, with signs of overdose, but also decrease or remain stable.
Comment: Clinical monitoring and testing of the plasma concentrations of phenytoin.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the diazepam, with risk of overdose, due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Clinical monitoring and plasma dosage, when that is possible, of the anticonvulsant taken with the stiripentol and possible adjustment of the dosage of the anticonvulsant taken with it as well.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of didanosine and of its undesirable effects

Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the didanosine, and especially the mitochondrial toxicity, due to substantial increase of its concentrations. In addition, risk of decrease of the effectiveness of the ganciclovir due to decrease of its concentrations, if the two medications are ingested in an interval of less than 2 hours
Increased risk of onset of pancreatitis due to addition of undesirable effects
Comment: Monitoring of the blood amylase level. Do not use these two medications together if the blood amylase level is at the high range of normal.

Description: Risk of increase of the mitochrondrial toxicity of the didanosine due to increase of its active metabolite
Risk of failure of the antiretroviral treatment, even emergence of resistance. In addition, increase of the risk of the mitchondrial toxicity of the didanosine
Increased risk of onset of peripheral neuropathy due to addition of undesirable effects
Comment: Regular clinical and biological monitoring, especially at the beginning of the administration of the two substances together.

Description: Increased risk of onset of pancreatitis and of peripheral neuropathy due to addition of undesirable effects
Comment: Regular clinical monitoring and monitoring of the amylasemia. Do not administer these substances together if the amylasemia is at the high range of normal.

Description: Depression of self-regulation (excessive bradycardia) and difficulties with atrioventricular conduction. In addition, increase of the digoninemia due to decrease of the clearance of digoxin
Comment: Clinical monitoring, EKG, and, if there is reason for it, testing of the digoxinemia and adjustment of the dosage.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia due to increase of its absorption
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possibly monitoring of the digoxinemia during treatment with the azithromycin and after it is stopped.

Description: Difficulties with autoregulation (bradycardia, sinus arrest) and difficulties with sinoauricular and atrioventricular conduction
Risk of serious arrhythmias, even lethal ones with the calcium salts administered via IV
Comment: -with the calcium salts by IV route, except for parenteral supplementation.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of carbamazepine and decrease of the digoxinemia
Comment: Exercise caution in the interpretation of the plasma concentrations.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia due to increase of its absorption
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possibly monitoring of the digoxinemia during the treatment with the clarithromycin and after it is stopped.

Description: Depression of autoregulation (excessive bradycardia) and disorders of atrioventricular conduction. In addition, increase of the digoxinemia due to decrease of the metabolism of the digoxin. Clinical monitoring and EKG.
Comment: Reduce the doses of digoxin by half.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia due to increase of its absorption
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possibly monitoring of the digoxinemia during the treatment with the erythromycin and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia due to decrease of the renal clearance of the digoxin. In addition, disorders of autoregulation (excessive bradycardia and disorders of atrioventricular conduction).
Comment: Clinical monitoring and EKG. In the case of unexpected results, test the digoxinemia and adjust the dosage.

Description: Hypokaliemia producing toxic effects of the digitalics
Comment: Correct beforehand all hypokaliemia and do clinical, electrolytic, and EKG monitoring.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia, more marked for IV route, due to increase of the absorption of the digoxin or decrease of its renal clearance.
Comment: Clinical monitoring and, if there is reason for them, EKG and monitoring of the digoxinemia, with possible adjustment of the dosage of digoxin.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia with nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias.
Comment: Clinical monitoring, and, if there is reason for them, EKG, and monitoring of the digoxinemia with adjustment of the dosage of the digoxin during the treatment with the itraconazole and after it is stopped.

Description: Difficulties with autoregulation (increase of the bradycardia inducing effect of the midodrine) and difficulties with atrioventricular conduction.
Comment: If this combination cannot be avoided, reinforce clinical monitoring and EKG.

Description: Decrease of the digoxinemia, by reason of the enzyme inducer effect of the St Johns wort, with risk of reduction of effectiveness, even complete loss of the effect, which can have possibly serious consequences (acute decompensated heart failure).
Comment: In the case of the two substances being taken together by accident, do not stop the St Johns wort abruptly, but test the plasma concentrations (or the effectiveness) of the digoxin before and then after the St Johns wort is stopped.

Description: Moderate increase of the digoxinemia due to increase of its absorption by the omeprazole
Comment: Clinical monitoring, EKG, and monitoring of the digoxinemia, particularly with an older patient.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia with nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias.
Comment: Clinical monitoring, and, if there is reason for them, EKG and monitoring of the digoxinemia, with adjustment of the dosage of the digxoin during the treatment with the posaconazole and after it is stopped.

Description: Risk of increase of the digoxinemia, especially with older patients
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possibly monitoring of the digoxinemia during the treatment with propafenone and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia due to decrease of the renal clearance of the digoxin. In addition, disorders of autoregulation (excessive bradycardia and disorders of atrioventricular conduction)
Comment: Clinical monitoring and EKG. In the case of an unexpected result, test the digoxinemia and adjust the dosage.

Description: Moderate increase of the digoxinemia
Comment: Clinical monitoring and EKG, if needed, with possible adjustment of the doses of digoxin.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia
Comment: Clinical, biological, and possibly EKG monitoring. Adjustment of the dosage of the digoxin if needed.

Description: Decrease of the digestive absorption of the digoxin
Comment: Take the sucralfate at a different time from the digoxin (more than 2 hours apart, if possible).

Description: Decrease of the digoxinemia that can reach 50%
Comment: Clinical monitoring, EKG, and, possibly, monitoring of the digoxinemia. If there is reason for it, adjustment of the dosage of the digoxin during the treatment with the sulfasalazine and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia
Comment: Clinical and biological monitoring, and adjustment, if needed, of the dosage of the digoxin during the treatment with the telaprevir and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the digoxinemia due to increase of its absorption
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possibly monitoring of the digoxinemia during the treatment with the telithromycin and after it is stopped

Description: Excessive bradycardia and atrioventricular block due to increase of the effects of the digoxin on autoregulation and conduction and due to decrease of the renal and extra-renal elimination of the digoxin
Comment: Clinical monitoring, EKG, and, possibly, testing of the digoxinemia. If there is reason for it, adjustment of the dosage of the digoxin during the treatment with the verapamil and after it is stopped.

Description: Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic metabolism of the alkaloid of ergot of rye).
Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic metabolism of the alkaloid of ergot of rye).
Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic metabolism of the alkaloid of ergot of rye).
Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic elimination of the alkaloid of ergot of rye).
Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic metabolism of the alkaloid of ergot of rye).
Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic elimination of the alkaloid of ergot of rye).
Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic metabolism of the alkaloid of ergot of rye).
Comment: Wait 24 hours between stopping the triclabendazole and the dose of the medication derived from ergot of rye, and the reverse.

Description: Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic metabolism of the alkaloid of ergot of rye).

Hypotension, heart failure with patients having latent or uncontrolled cardiac insufficiency (addition of the negative inotropic effects). The beta blocking agent can furthermore minimize the sympathetic reflex reaction brought into play in the case of excessive hemodynamic repercussion

Hypotension, heart failure in patients with latent or uncontrolled cardiac insufficiency (negative inotropic effect of the dihydropyridines in vitro, more or less marked, and susceptible of adding to the negative inotropic effects of the beta blocking agents). The presence of a beta-blocking treatment can furthermore minimize the sympathetic reflex reaction put into play in cases of excessive hemodynamic repercussion.

With the dantrolene administered via IV: with animals, fatal cases of ventricular fibrillations are constantly observed when verapamil and dantrolene are administered via IV route. The administration of a calcium channel blocker and dantrolene together is thus potentially dangerous. However, some patients have received nifedipine and dantrolene together without incident.
Increase of the opioid analgesic's effect of respiratory depression due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Adjust the dosage of the alfentanil when there is treatment with the diltiazem.

Description: For diltiazem by injection: risk of bradycardia and of atrioventricular blockFor diltiazem by mouth: risk of bradycardia or of atrioventricular block, especially in older persons.
Comment: -with diltiazem administered intravenously

Description: Increased risk of undesirable effects (concentration-dependant) of the rhabodmyolysis type due to decrease of the hepatic metabolism of the cholesterol lowering agent
Comment: Use weaker doses of the cholesterol lowering agent or another statin not affected by this type of interaction.

Description: Disorders of autoregulation (excessive bradycardia, sinus arrest), disorders of sinoatrial and atrioventricular conduction, and cardiac failure
Comment: The administration of these medications together should only be done under strict clinical monitoring and EKG, in particular with older patients or at the beginning of treatment.

Description: Negative inotropic effect with risk of acute decompensated heart failure, disorders of autoregulation (bradycardia, sinus arrest), and disorders of sinoatrial and atrioventricular conduction
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the buspirone due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the diltiazem, with increase of its undesirable effects
Comment: Clinical monitoring and adjustment of the dosage of the buspirone if necessary.

Description: Disorders of autoregulation (disorders of atrioventricular conduction due to addition of the negative effects on conduction)

With the dantrolene administered by IV: with animals, fatal cases of ventricular fibrillations are constantly observed when verapamil and dantrolene are administered by IV route. The administration of a calcium channel blocker and dantolene together is thus potentially dangerous. However, some patients have received nifedipine and dantolene together without incident
Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic metabolism of the alkaloid of ergot of rye).

Risk of bradycardia or of atrioventricular block, especially with older patients. Furthermore, slight increase of the concentrations of dronedarone due to decrease of its metabolism by the calcium channel blocker
Comment: Begin the treatment with the calcium channel blocker at the minimum recommended dosages and adjust the doses according to the EKG.

Description: Ergotism with possibility of necrosis of the extremities (inhibition of the hepatic metabolism of the alkaloid of ergot of rye)
Disorders of autoregulation (excessive bradycardia, sinus arrest), disorders of sinoatrial and atrioventricular conduction, and cardiac arrest.
Comment: -in case of alteration of left ventricular function

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of ibrutinib due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the diltiazem
Comment: Strict clinical monitoring and reduction of the dose of ibrutinib to 140 mg/day during the length of time that these medications are administered together.

Description: Increase of the blood concentrations of the immunosuppressant due to decrease of its metabolism
Comment: Blood concentration dosage of the immunosuppressant, testing of renal function, and adjustment of the dosage during the treatment with these medications together and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the ivabradine and of its undesirable effects, especially cardiac ones (inhibition of its hepatic metabolism by the diltiazem), that add to the bradycardia inducing effects of these molecules.
Increase of the plasma concentrations of midazolam due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism, with increase of sedation
Comment: Clinical monitoring and reduction of the dosage during the treatment with the diltiazem

Description: Large increase of the concentrations of nefidipine due to decrease of its hepatic metabolism by the diltiazem, with risk of severe hypotension
Increase of the plasma concentrations of olaparib by the diltiazem
Comment: If administering these together cannot be avoided, limit the dose of olaparib to 200 mg twice a day.

Description: Increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias, especially of torsades de pointes
Increased risk of undesirable effects (concentration-dependant) of the rhabdomyolysis type, due to decrease of the hepatic metabolism of the cholesterol lowering agent
Comment: Do not exceed the dosage of 20 mg/day of simvastatin. If the therapeutic objective is not reached at this dosage, use another statin not affected by this type of interaction

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the tamsulosine, due to inhibition of its hepatic metabolism
Comment: Clinical monitoring and adjustment of the dosage of the tamsulosine during the treatment with the enzymatic inhibitor and after it is stopped, if the situation requires.

Description: Risk of increase of the plasma concentrations of ticagrelor due to decrease of its hepatic metabolsim
Increase of the plasma concentrations of the hydroquinidine and risk of overdose (decrease of the renal excretion of the hydroquinidine by alkalinizing of the urine)
Comment: Clinical monitoring, EKG, and possibly testing of the concentrations of the hydroquinidine; if needed, adjustment of the dosage during the alkalinizing treatment and after it is stopped.

Description: Increase of the plasma concentrations of the quinidine and risk of overdose (decrease of the renal excretion of the quinidine by alkalinizing of the urine).
Comment: Clinical monitoring, EKG, and possibly testing of the concentrations of quinidine; if needed, adjustment of the dosage during the alkalinizing treatment and after it is stopped.

Description: Possible increase of the risk of infection
Risk of overdose due to increase of the plasma concentrations of diprophylline (inhibition of its renal tubular secretion)
Comment: Reduce the dosage of diprophylline during the treatment with the probenicid

Description: With the dipyridamole by injection: reduction of the vasodilator effect of the dipyridamole by the theine
Comment: Avoid the consumption of theine based products during the 24 hours before myocardial perfusion imaging with dipyridamole

Description: With the dipyridamole by injection: increase of the antihypertensive effect
With the dipyridamole by injection: reduction of the vasodilator effect of the dipyridamole by the caffeine
Comment: Interrupt a caffeine based treatment at least 5 days before myocardial perfusion imaging with the dipyridamole and avoid consuming coffee, tea, chocolate, or cola during the 24 hours that precede the test.

Description: With the dipyridamole by injection: reduction of the vasodilator effect of the dipyridamole by the theophylline
Comment: Interrupt a treatment with theophylline at lease 5 days before myocardial perfusion imaging with the dipyridamole.

Description: Risk of decrease of the concentrations of the disopyramide by the inducer.
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possibly adjustment of the dosage of the disopyramide during the administration of these medications together and 1 to 2 weeks after the inducer is stopped.

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the disopyramide due to decrease of its metabolism.
Comment: Clinical monitoring and possible adjustment of the dosage of the disopyramide

Description: Risk of increase of the undesirable effects of the disopyramide: severe hypoglycemia, lengthening of the QT interval, and serious ventricular arrhythmias, especially of the torsade de pointes type.
Comment: Regular clinical, biological and EKG monitoring,

Description: Increase of the effect of the vitamin K antagonist and of the risk of hemorrhage
Comment: More frequent testing of the INR. Adjustment of the dosage of the vitamin K antagonist during the treatment with the disulfiram and a week after it is stopped

Description: Increase of the concentrations of cocaine due to decrease of its metabolism by the disulfirame, with risk of increase of inducing torsades de pointes
Disorders of behavior and of coordination
Risk of episodes of acute psychosis or confused state, reversible upon stopping the administration of the two substances together
Large and rapid increase of the plasma concentrations of phenytoin with signs of toxicity (inhibition of its metabolism)
Comment: If the administration of these substances together cannot be avoided, clinical monitoring and monitoring of the plasma concentrations of phenytoin during the treatment with the disulfiram and after it is stopped.

Description: For anti-inflammatory doses of acetylsalicylic acid (>=1gr per dose and/or >=3gr per day) or for analgesic or antipyretic doses (>=500 mg per dose and/or <3 gr per day):Acute renal insufficiency in dehydrated patients due to decrease of the glomerular filtration as a result of a decrease of the synthesis of the renal prostaglandins. Furthermore, reduction of the anti-hypertensive effect.
Comment: Hydrate the patient and monitor renal function at the start of treatment.

Description: Acute renal insufficiency with the patient at risk (older patient and/or dehydrated one) due to decrease of the glomerular filtration (inhibition of the vasodilator prostaglandins due to the NSAIs). Furthermore, reduction of the antihypertensive effect
Comment: Hydrate the patient and monitor renal function at the start of treatment

Description: In case of dehydration caused by the diuretics, increased risk of acute functional renal insufficiency, in particular when large doses of the contrast media are used.
Comment: Rehydrate before administration of the iodinated product

Description: Increase of the nephrotoxic and ototoxic risks of the aminoglycoside (functional renal insufficiency linked to the dehydration caused by the diuretic)
Increase of the lithemia with signs of overdose of lithium as with a low sodium regimen (decrease of the urinary excretion of the lithium)
Lactic acidosis due to the metformin, set into action by a possible functional renal insufficiency, linked to the loop diuretics
Risk of addition of the ototoxic and/or nephrotoxic effects

Drug 2 Class Name: OTHER POTASSIUM SPARING DIURETICS (ALONE OR IN COMBINATION)

Comment: Inform the patient, strengthen self-monitoring of blood glucose, and possibly adjust the dosage of the blood glucose lowering sulfonamide during the treatment with the erythromycin.

Description: Increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias, especially of torsades de pointes
